headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Maria, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] After the speakers' remarks, there wil
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Maria, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Clem Teng to begin. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, s
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC.
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, August 3, 2012, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and the audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. Our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.62 compared to $1.43 last year, a 13% increase. Five items contributed to this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 8.3% adding $0.12 per share. Our non-same-store pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. Our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.62 compared to $1.43 last year, a 13% increase. Five items contributed to this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 8.3% adding $0.12 per share. Our non-same-store properties added $0.03. Last year's acquisition of affiliated partnership interests added $0.02, lower financing costs other added $0.04, ancillary operations primarily our tenant reinsurance business added $0.01. Partially offsetting this was $0.03 per share from lower interest income. 
We completed several capital transactions in the second quarter. We issued $288 million of preferred securities at a rate of 5 5/8 and called for redemption $416 million with an average rate of 6.7%. Assuming no further reissuances, preferred dividends are expected to be about $8 million lower in the third quarter of 2012 as compared to last year. 
With that, I will now turn it over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Second quarter benefited from solid demand resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q2, we reduced media spend by 44% or about $1.5 million, as well as promotional discounts. Net customer acquisition cost decli
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Second quarter benefited from solid demand resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q2, we reduced media spend by 44% or about $1.5 million, as well as promotional discounts. 
Net customer acquisition cost declined as customer move-in volumes remained constant despite lower media and promotional discounts. At the end of July 2012, occupancy asking rents and in-place rents were all higher than the same period last year. 
In Q2, Denver and Charlotte markets led the country with revenue growth of 8.7% followed by Miami, Detroit at 6.6%. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew 4.4%, and San Francisco, our second largest market, grew -- revenues increased by 6.2%. 
Given the trends in our occupancies and rates, we expect our Q3 media spend will be comparable to last year. In Europe, same-store NOI improved 2% despite a challenging operating environment. 
We recently completed the purchase of 5 facilities with about 377,000 square feet for $52 million. We're currently the contract to acquire 2 more facilities for about $30 million. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just in regards to Europe, your occupancy has slipped a little bit overall even from Q1, but you've still been able to see some decent growth in realized rents. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about your overall revenue management strategy th
componenttext: Just in regards to Europe, your occupancy has slipped a little bit overall even from Q1, but you've still been able to see some decent growth in realized rents. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about your overall revenue management strategy there, and what makes sense sort of given the different environment you're operating in versus the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Christy, last year, we had some real aggressive promotional discounts in a couple of markets, which we did not do this year because the -- we kind of didn't get the benefit in terms of rate and promotional discounts versus move-in volume, but we've modera
componenttext: Christy, last year, we had some real aggressive promotional discounts in a couple of markets, which we did not do this year because the -- we kind of didn't get the benefit in terms of rate and promotional discounts versus move-in volume, but we've moderated those this year. So you've seen some degradation in occupancy and an uptick in the in-place rents and the rental revenue, lower promotional discounts. That varies by market, and the operating results vary greatly by market on a revenue growth basis. France was down 1.6% on same-store basis whereas the U.K. was up 3.5%, and Belgium was up almost 7%. So it varies by market. So what you're seeing is a blend, but the big picture is better pricing reduced discounts this year with some impact on move-in volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the U.K. Can you talk about how the VAT tax issue could potentially impact the platform overall? I wasn't sure sort of what the breakout looks like in terms of residential versus commercial? And how does it impact sort of your perspec
componenttext: Just following up on the U.K. Can you talk about how the VAT tax issue could potentially impact the platform overall? I wasn't sure sort of what the breakout looks like in terms of residential versus commercial? And how does it impact sort of your perspective about investing additional capital there?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a lot of questions there. Basically, I don't think -- I think the VAT tax is going to be negative. That's effectively a 20% price increase, and we've been told that, in fact, that's going in place October 1. So my guess is it will be negative
componenttext: Well, that's a lot of questions there. Basically, I don't think -- I think the VAT tax is going to be negative. That's effectively a 20% price increase, and we've been told that, in fact, that's going in place October 1. So my guess is it will be negative. How much, we don't know. I think we have 25%, 30% business customers. So obviously, they won't pay it. The retail customer will be paying it.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Eric Wolfe with Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Eric Wolfe with Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's actually Michael Bilerman. I'm just curious with occupancy getting back towards what is historically peak-ish levels more of your revenue growth coming from rate, how much further do you think you can push rate increases on your customers and sort of
componenttext: It's actually Michael Bilerman. I'm just curious with occupancy getting back towards what is historically peak-ish levels more of your revenue growth coming from rate, how much further do you think you can push rate increases on your customers and sort of where are you sort of sending that renewal today?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is John. Yes, we are still pushing rental rate increases to existing tenants. We're sending that as many renewals this year as we did last year. The rate increases are higher this year than last year. Can we continue to do that into next yea
componenttext: Michael, this is John. Yes, we are still pushing rental rate increases to existing tenants. We're sending that as many renewals this year as we did last year. The rate increases are higher this year than last year. Can we continue to do that into next year? We're going to continue to try to do that. We see no reason why we couldn't do that. Part of our revenue growth was also driven by reductions in discounts as Ron mentioned. So we picked up a good chunk of growth in the second quarter by reducing discounts to those new incoming tenants. So we're continuing to drive our revenues mostly with increases to existing tenants but also with reduced discounts to new incoming tenants.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And what would the discounts have been in terms of the spread relative to last year in terms of impact to revenues?
componenttext: And what would the discounts have been in terms of the spread relative to last year in terms of impact to revenues?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Probably the spread is probably close to 100 bps of growth in the second quarter.
componenttext: Probably the spread is probably close to 100 bps of growth in the second quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And you would expect this 5% growth to continue in the back half of the year assuming occupancy is flat to up a little bit?
componenttext: And you would expect this 5% growth to continue in the back half of the year assuming occupancy is flat to up a little bit?

componenttext: As you know, we don't give guidance, Michael. So...

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Trying get to a sense of how you're trying to pressure customers, that's all.
componenttext: Trying get to a sense of how you're trying to pressure customers, that's all.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm along with Jordan Sadler as well. Just a quick follow-up on that. I just was wondering if you could breakout in terms of the top line growth what the impact was from reduced concessions versus higher market rents.
componenttext: I'm along with Jordan Sadler as well. Just a quick follow-up on that. I just was wondering if you could breakout in terms of the top line growth what the impact was from reduced concessions versus higher market rents.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, again the growth that we experienced was probably driven by increases to existing tenants. That's primarily the biggest driver. And as I mentioned to Michael on the previous color that we drove growth about 100 basis points by reduced discounts. Mar
componenttext: Well, again the growth that we experienced was probably driven by increases to existing tenants. That's primarily the biggest driver. And as I mentioned to Michael on the previous color that we drove growth about 100 basis points by reduced discounts. Market rent, those that are charged that are theoretically charged to new move-ins although our market rents are higher rents that are actually taken by the move-ins were about flat year-over-year, and our move-in volume as I mentioned was about flat year-over-year. So we really didn't drive revenue on the new move-in customer with the exception of reduced discounts to them. But on the peer volume and rate to those customers, it was a basically a push on a year-to-year basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron or John, can you just sort of following on our last comment, John, can just give us a sense for the year-over-year change, and sort of the relationship between street rents and your in-place rents?
componenttext: Ron or John, can you just sort of following on our last comment, John, can just give us a sense for the year-over-year change, and sort of the relationship between street rents and your in-place rents?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Street rents, Michael, are all over the place depending obviously, which part of the country we're in. We were probably up anywhere from 3% to 5%, but with that said, we discount occasionally off of those. If a customer comes in via the Web, there's a dis
componenttext: Street rents, Michael, are all over the place depending obviously, which part of the country we're in. We were probably up anywhere from 3% to 5%, but with that said, we discount occasionally off of those. If a customer comes in via the Web, there's a discount. Again, the actual rate that's taken was about flat. In terms of the in-place rent, the in-place rent is still it fluctuates depending on the time of the year because we drive street rents, which can then go higher than in-place rents. And throughout the quarter, it was probably about 5% on a year-over-year basis. But let me see if I can answer your question different way because it might be what you're really looking for. People were moving at roughly $114 per unit on rent. They were moving out at about $125 during the quarter. And net-net, on just pure rate alone, we were in a rent roll down, which we were last year also, but I think that's really the question that you're trying to fish for.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and then maybe can you just talk a little bit about your Internet marketing strategy and kind of your view of degree that, that is a competitive advantage for you over -- certainly over your private competitors and maybe to some extent, ev
componenttext: That's helpful, and then maybe can you just talk a little bit about your Internet marketing strategy and kind of your view of degree that, that is a competitive advantage for you over -- certainly over your private competitors and maybe to some extent, even how you feel about that versus your public competitors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, I'll start big picture on the Internet. Last time I looked at it, we get 75%, 80% of our inquiries organically. That means we don't have to pay for them, and that's certainly attributable to the brand name. When we talk to the experts at th
componenttext: Well, Michael, I'll start big picture on the Internet. Last time I looked at it, we get 75%, 80% of our inquiries organically. That means we don't have to pay for them, and that's certainly attributable to the brand name. When we talk to the experts at the search firms and Google, that's a pretty unparalleled level of organic search not just in our industry, but across industries in the U.S. So I would say our brand has a tremendous benefit to us on the Web and obviously, a lower cost to drive Internet traffic vis-à-vis our competitors and the local operators. As time has gone on, we continue to drive more traffic through the Web so more of our volume is coming through there, and you can see that in our Internet spend, which is probably up $1 million, $1.5 million year-over-year. But our costs per click is continuing to go down. So we're getting more volume but the cost of each of that customer is less than it was a year ago. I don't know if that addresses everything you were trying to ask.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's fascinating color. If I can just follow up real quick just related to that. What percentage of your customers overall come from the Internet as opposed to walk in or over the phone I guess?
componenttext: That's fascinating color. If I can just follow up real quick just related to that. What percentage of your customers overall come from the Internet as opposed to walk in or over the phone I guess?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, roughly 60% of our tenants appeared to have come to us from the Internet. The reason why I say appeared because some of them make reservations on our website, and some of them call our call center using the telephone number that they got from our
componenttext: Michael, roughly 60% of our tenants appeared to have come to us from the Internet. The reason why I say appeared because some of them make reservations on our website, and some of them call our call center using the telephone number that they got from our website. If you combine those 2 together, they didn't make a reservation on the website, but they've made a reservation at a call center. So we kind of combined those 2, and so roughly about 60% of our tenants are coming to us or at least those that make reservations moving in are coming to us via the Web and our website.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of [indiscernible].
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of [indiscernible].

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your capital transactions, do you have more where that is leading this year?
componenttext: Your capital transactions, do you have more where that is leading this year?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We do. We have in addition to the step that we've  already called, there is -- we've got about 5 other series of preferreds that are callable. 2 of them, the 2 highest coupon ones that are probably the next ones that we did desire to call are series X and
componenttext: We do. We have in addition to the step that we've  already called, there is -- we've got about 5 other series of preferreds that are callable. 2 of them, the 2 highest coupon ones that are probably the next ones that we did desire to call are series X and Series F. Both of those have a coupon of about 6 45, and combined, they're about close to $400 million.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, and second, switching gears. I think on the call you mentioned that rents and occupancy are trending higher as of July. I was wondering if you provided any numbers on that?
componenttext: Okay, and second, switching gears. I think on the call you mentioned that rents and occupancy are trending higher as of July. I was wondering if you provided any numbers on that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I didn't, but I'll give them to you. So at the end of July, occupancy was 93 1 versus 92 9 last year.
componenttext: I didn't, but I'll give them to you. So at the end of July, occupancy was 93 1 versus 92 9 last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you're looking at the domestic portfolio, expense growth has been muted for a long time this quarter. I think that was actually down year-over-year. Can you talk about when do you see like how far away are you from something that feels
componenttext: I was wondering if you're looking at the domestic portfolio, expense growth has been muted for a long time this quarter. I think that was actually down year-over-year. Can you talk about when do you see like how far away are you from something that feels like it's more normalized rate of expense growth?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Ron. The big swing variable in our expenses year-over-year has really been in the media advertising, the television, which I touched on as we've been able to reduce that by year-over-year on a same-store pool $2.5 million. In aggregate, it's
componenttext: Mike, this is Ron. The big swing variable in our expenses year-over-year has really been in the media advertising, the television, which I touched on as we've been able to reduce that by year-over-year on a same-store pool $2.5 million. In aggregate, it's partly close to $3.5 million but $2.5 million in same-store pool while maintaining moving volume and reducing promotional discounts. Q3 media spend, as I touched on, will probably be comparable to last year. So if I just look at Q2, we had a 43% reduction in media spend. We're not going to have that going into Q3. The other items, the big swing items, utilities, it's been a milder second quarter weather-wise, but pretty hot in July and August across parts of the country. So my guess is utilities will swing the other way. Property level costs and I assume pretty well flat, maybe up a little bit. Property taxes are the big item. It's our largest expense. We're running about 4%. John?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Still our estimates about a 4% increase throughout the full year, Michael.
componenttext: Still our estimates about a 4% increase throughout the full year, Michael.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neil of RBC Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neil of RBC Capital.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. One more general, and then one more I guess specific operationally. Given that some of your other peers have been doing significant amount of acquisitions relative to their size, what is preventing you from sort of doing the same? I me
componenttext: I have 2 questions. One more general, and then one more I guess specific operationally. Given that some of your other peers have been doing significant amount of acquisitions relative to their size, what is preventing you from sort of doing the same? I mean, you have a pretty cheap cost of equity. I mean, are you looking at things, portfolio sales maybe, something like in California or Texas or the East Coast to sort of drive your growth going forward just given your where you're trading at NAV versus your stock price or do you want to keep the same I guess portfolio size? What are your thoughts about that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things, Neil. First of all, I don't think we have any peers, but -- second of all, I think if you run through the model, run through one of your models, if we did $1 billion of acquisitions, use preferred call it 5 1/4, and we bought $1
componenttext: Well, a couple of things, Neil. First of all, I don't think we have any peers, but -- second of all, I think if you run through the model, run through one of your models, if we did $1 billion of acquisitions, use preferred call it 5 1/4, and we bought $1 billion let's say 6 and a 6 yield is 100 basis points wide of the large New York portfolio we've done last year. We had 50 to 75 bps on yield on $1 billion. So you're talking $5 million or $6 million. I don't think if you run it through your model, you see that, that has a huge impact on our earnings growth. The second part is there's not $1 billion of any property in any markets to be had. If you look at the acquisitions in the first half of the year, all the public companies combined, I think they bought about $200 million excluding stuff that they bought from joint ventures. So and I'll just assume everyone's buying A properties in A markets is only $200 million first half of the year. I'd like to assume it's $400 million or $500 million run rate. So there's just not a lot of A product in A markets coming to the marketplace right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, my follow-up is and given your occupancy levels are now probably around the highest in several years, are you -- have you figured out the strategy of what sort of tenant, not business tenant obviously, sort of retail I guess you could call it tenant
componenttext: Okay, my follow-up is and given your occupancy levels are now probably around the highest in several years, are you -- have you figured out the strategy of what sort of tenant, not business tenant obviously, sort of retail I guess you could call it tenant to I guess to get to stay the longest before they move-out? So I guess in other words, because your occupancy's so high are you just going to look to push renewals very aggressively and see what sticks or are you sort of getting it from a I guess more technologically savvy perspective or target those tenants who can take those large renewals consistently?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: So, Neil, one of the things that we monitor is the number of customers in the portfolio of greater than 1 year, and that has been rising over the last couple of years. At the end of Q2, June 30, it was about 54.9%, which is up from 54.7% in 2011 and up fr
componenttext: So, Neil, one of the things that we monitor is the number of customers in the portfolio of greater than 1 year, and that has been rising over the last couple of years. At the end of Q2, June 30, it was about 54.9%, which is up from 54.7% in 2011 and up from 54% in 2010. So that number has been moving up year-over-year. It varies slightly by quarter due to seasonality, but quarter-over-quarter, it's continue to increase. We pay attention to that because that's really the base of customers that we have that we target to send our rental rate increases. So it's important that, that group continue to grow. The second aspect of it is rental rate increases have a direct impact on people's length of stay, which is intuitively a 3% rental rate increase, they're going to get a different move-out rate than if you send them a 30% rental rate increase. So we monitor that very carefully in terms of the level of rental rate increases we send out versus our change in move-out volume. It's not directed so much whether they're a business customer or a consumer. It's more how we're monitoring the rental rate increases than it's impact on our move-out volume. John, you have anything to add?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, and Neil, it depends on the market and the property we look at each of those factors the demography, move-out rates, what happens to them after we do give increases, how much long -- how quickly do they move-out because there is an uptick in move-out
componenttext: No, and Neil, it depends on the market and the property we look at each of those factors the demography, move-out rates, what happens to them after we do give increases, how much long -- how quickly do they move-out because there is an uptick in move-out activity, and we weigh that versus how much of an increase we're going to give particular customers within certain markets and certain properties. So it's all kind of into the mix because at the end of the day, we are trying to optimize our revenues without totally having people pack up and move.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you give some more details on the acquisitions you made in the quarter and then the one you made in July just looking at occupancy and pricing?
componenttext: Can you give some more details on the acquisitions you made in the quarter and then the one you made in July just looking at occupancy and pricing?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Stuff we bought during the quarter. [indiscernible] Going back in my mind what we bought in the quarter versus recently. The stuff we bought in the first half of the year, most of it was bank foreclosures. The occupancies were fairly low. We've got anothe
componenttext: Stuff we bought during the quarter. [indiscernible] Going back in my mind what we bought in the quarter versus recently. The stuff we bought in the first half of the year, most of it was bank foreclosures. The occupancies were fairly low. We've got another one of those to close on I think in August, and then about 4 or 5 of the properties were more stabilized private transactions negotiated with private owners. They had a higher stabilized occupancy not 90%, but closer to 75%, 80%. Is that what you're looking for?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was kind of going for you. Probably would err on the side of more lease-up opportunities?
componenttext: Yes, that was kind of going for you. Probably would err on the side of more lease-up opportunities?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is kind of bad, but the great thing about the short sales, the bank foreclosure stuff is they're generally under managed under occupied and acquired at pretty good discounts replacement cost. So if I could buy 1 billion of those, that would be f
componenttext: Yes, this is kind of bad, but the great thing about the short sales, the bank foreclosure stuff is they're generally under managed under occupied and acquired at pretty good discounts replacement cost. So if I could buy 1 billion of those, that would be fantastic. But they're hard to come by. They're challenging to negotiate through the sellers, through the banks, but they're a great long-term value add to the portfolio.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Are the low in the sense that they were newly built over the last couple of years or not necessarily?
componenttext: Are the low in the sense that they were newly built over the last couple of years or not necessarily?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, the stuff we bought in July had been open 4 or 5 years it was managed by a public company but it just wasn't run well, and the other problem with that is banks they're generally not get the capital, needed capital into the property. So anyone managing
componenttext: No, the stuff we bought in July had been open 4 or 5 years it was managed by a public company but it just wasn't run well, and the other problem with that is banks they're generally not get the capital, needed capital into the property. So anyone managing is going to have a challenge achieving good occupancies because they can't make the investment to space mix changes, water leaks, roof, those kinds of things. So when we buy them, we like that. We can easily refit them, rebrand them and then get them to our 92%, 93% occupancy.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is there a CapEx per square foot number that you kind of earmarked for new acquisitions like that?
componenttext: Is there a CapEx per square foot number that you kind of earmarked for new acquisitions like that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: It varies deal by deal. It really does. So we're looking at all-in costs, the rebranding costs. One of the acquisitions we did, we had to buy a parcel of land behind it so we could create another entranceway into the property, but that was all factored in
componenttext: It varies deal by deal. It really does. So we're looking at all-in costs, the rebranding costs. One of the acquisitions we did, we had to buy a parcel of land behind it so we could create another entranceway into the property, but that was all factored in when we underwrote the transaction.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: A question about.
componenttext: A question about.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to our next question from David Harris of Imperial Capital.
componenttext: We'll move on to our next question from David Harris of Imperial Capital.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for you, Ron, on Europe. Over the last couple of quarters, you referred to some management challenges and operational challenges in the Netherlands. Are you beyond that now?
componenttext: A couple of questions for you, Ron, on Europe. Over the last couple of quarters, you referred to some management challenges and operational challenges in the Netherlands. Are you beyond that now?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: David, I think we're getting there. If I look at Holland while year-over-year occupancy is down 3.6% with 75 at the end of the quarter versus 77 last year, but the revenue growth has still declined about 2%. But that rate of growth is slowed. We've got a
componenttext: David, I think we're getting there. If I look at Holland while year-over-year occupancy is down 3.6% with 75 at the end of the quarter versus 77 last year, but the revenue growth has still declined about 2%. But that rate of growth is slowed. We've got a good team in there, and so I think we'll see Holland, maybe not this year but next year turn positive for us and will push the occupancies in that market. So I'm feeling pretty good about Holland. Our new CEO over there is doing a great job. He's done field operations a lot. So I think he's gaining traction. The market that's kind of started hurting us is our largest market, France, where we're backwards on occupancy there as well, 2.8%. Revenue growth is down 1.6%, but that market has gotten pretty soft over the last 6 months.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Do you think that's associated with the political change or the slowdown in the economy or is it more specific to your business?
componenttext: Do you think that's associated with the political change or the slowdown in the economy or is it more specific to your business?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think there's in general, in France, I don't know in June or July, there's a proposal to increase wages for everyone over there by I think 2% or 3%, and so and our workers in France unionized. So they decided to go on strike for a day to emphasize that
componenttext: I think there's in general, in France, I don't know in June or July, there's a proposal to increase wages for everyone over there by I think 2% or 3%, and so and our workers in France unionized. So they decided to go on strike for a day to emphasize that they wanted that 2% or 3% wage increase. We have various things like that challenging us in France.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is a bigger-picture question. Is it premature to think about good opportunities arising over the next couple of years out of the financial dislocation, economic disruption that we're seeing in the continent?
componenttext: This is a bigger-picture question. Is it premature to think about good opportunities arising over the next couple of years out of the financial dislocation, economic disruption that we're seeing in the continent?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you have to step back, David. In Europe, there's 1,200, 1,400 facilities. Probably half of them are not even product we would want, maybe even 3/4 of them. Europe is really more of a development opportunity. There really quality portfolios take. I
componenttext: I think you have to step back, David. In Europe, there's 1,200, 1,400 facilities. Probably half of them are not even product we would want, maybe even 3/4 of them. Europe is really more of a development opportunity. There really quality portfolios take. It's not over leverage. It's well-run, smart group of guys running the portfolio. There's some regional operators over there that also have some quality assets, but to our knowledge, they're not over leverage so they're not in financial distribution. So there's not a lot of distressed product of quality as best we can tell available in Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. The external dimensions your growth story over time is really more development story than acquisitions then?
componenttext: Okay. The external dimensions your growth story over time is really more development story than acquisitions then?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: In Europe, yes. But we call last I think we went through this last quarter, we're really focused on taking our cash flow in Europe and de-leveraging. So we can hopefully get to investment grade late 2013, early 2014. So that's really our principal focus i
componenttext: In Europe, yes. But we call last I think we went through this last quarter, we're really focused on taking our cash flow in Europe and de-leveraging. So we can hopefully get to investment grade late 2013, early 2014. So that's really our principal focus in terms of capital deployment in Europe is de-leveraging.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sorry about that. We moved offices and we're having technical difficulties. So my question was are you seeing any elevation in employee turnover either in the field or at the corporate headquarters as the job market slowly improves? And how do you think a
componenttext: Sorry about that. We moved offices and we're having technical difficulties. So my question was are you seeing any elevation in employee turnover either in the field or at the corporate headquarters as the job market slowly improves? And how do you think about staying ahead of that in terms of retention strategies?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paula, we have an excellent HR team headed up by Candy, and she works closely with Sean, our COO, and John. And they look at turnover all the time, and they look at recruiting across markets. In fact, we have a weekly meeting on new staffing, both at the
componenttext: Paula, we have an excellent HR team headed up by Candy, and she works closely with Sean, our COO, and John. And they look at turnover all the time, and they look at recruiting across markets. In fact, we have a weekly meeting on new staffing, both at the field level and the district manager level. So it's something we monitor very closely, but we've been fortunate on the property manager, relief manager side that our turnover is flat to down versus last year. And on the DM side, we're hiring fewer DMs this year because we've had a little less turnover. But on a District Manager side, we're challenged in markets that you would expect like Washington, D.C. Baltimore, which has incredibly low unemployment. So those markets are harder to fill, but overall, we're doing fine on the turnover side. We haven't noticed a big uptick. Corporate-wide, turnover is not really -- pretty low.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a follow-up on your comments regarding domestic acquisitions. I guess I'm just wondering all else being equal, given the free cash flow that you're throwing off $65 million, $75 million a quarter, would you rather pay down preferreds 6% or by an
componenttext: Yes, just a follow-up on your comments regarding domestic acquisitions. I guess I'm just wondering all else being equal, given the free cash flow that you're throwing off $65 million, $75 million a quarter, would you rather pay down preferreds 6% or by an asset 6% yield even if it is what you consider to be a Class B facility?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd rather grow our asset base than continue to de-leverage.
componenttext: Well, we'd rather grow our asset base than continue to de-leverage.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, I guess it seems like right now with some of the refinancing of the preferreds that you are de-leveraging the balance sheet a little bit. Do you have plans to continue in that direction or do you think that you'll bring leverage up a bit?
componenttext: Okay, well, I guess it seems like right now with some of the refinancing of the preferreds that you are de-leveraging the balance sheet a little bit. Do you have plans to continue in that direction or do you think that you'll bring leverage up a bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: It really just depends on the opportunity. As I touched on before, there's not a lot out there, but what is out there, we're trying to garner. We have system-wide or company-wide about $5 billion to $6 billion of preferred capacity. So we have plenty of f
componenttext: It really just depends on the opportunity. As I touched on before, there's not a lot out there, but what is out there, we're trying to garner. We have system-wide or company-wide about $5 billion to $6 billion of preferred capacity. So we have plenty of firepower. It's really just predicated on the right opportunity.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, it's Jordan. I guess trying to figure out are you cap rate sensitive? I know you talk a lot about and have for years about discount relative to replacement cost or replacement cost being something of a governor. And it's a little and actually I under
componenttext: Ron, it's Jordan. I guess trying to figure out are you cap rate sensitive? I know you talk a lot about and have for years about discount relative to replacement cost or replacement cost being something of a governor. And it's a little and actually I understand why, but given sort of lease-up timeframes I guess it's a little bit harder to gauge what lease-up cost is given how long it can take to lease-up. So I'm just curious, we're just curious are you cap rate sensitive in that even you have all this cash flow and the willingness and the ability to lever up if prices were to move in the direction of that initial cap rate stabilized assets had significantly lower than 6%, are you sensitive to that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We are more price per pound sensitive than cap rate sensitive. One of the properties we're acquiring in Q3, it's in New Jersey. It's $40 a foot, and I think on day 1, it has a negative yield. 30%, 40% occupied. It's a bank foreclosure, okay? At $40 a foot
componenttext: We are more price per pound sensitive than cap rate sensitive. One of the properties we're acquiring in Q3, it's in New Jersey. It's $40 a foot, and I think on day 1, it has a negative yield. 30%, 40% occupied. It's a bank foreclosure, okay? At $40 a foot, it's half the replacement cost throughout the deal. Would it take us a year or 2 to fill up? Maybe but $40 a foot we couldn't even fill it for half that. So we love that deal. The stuff we bought in the first quarter, which saw some back foreclosure blended cost of about $80 a foot our guess is that stuff on average would take about $120 a foot. I think we paid $45 million for that, and the going-in income was about less than $1 million if I recall. So again not going in cap rate sensitive. We're looking at it's a blended $80 a foot and $120 to build. Does that help you?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: It is. I guess I'm just curious is it -- how do you value lease-up? Let's say some things 30% leased, you can buy it at a 10% discount to replacement cost, but it's probably going to take -- it's in the market where it's going to take another 3 years to l
componenttext: It is. I guess I'm just curious is it -- how do you value lease-up? Let's say some things 30% leased, you can buy it at a 10% discount to replacement cost, but it's probably going to take -- it's in the market where it's going to take another 3 years to lease it up like what's the value do you think?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we impute a cost to carry to get it to a stabilized deal and our own internal analysis. So we try to discount back that. To your point, a property that has 3 years to lease-up is not -- it has a different value than one that is already stabilized. S
componenttext: Well, we impute a cost to carry to get it to a stabilized deal and our own internal analysis. So we try to discount back that. To your point, a property that has 3 years to lease-up is not -- it has a different value than one that is already stabilized. So we try to impute -- well, we don't try, we do impute our cost of capital our carrying cost associated with that. We're also stabilize properties. We bought in the second quarter, we bought 2 properties here in Southern California that one was I think 70%, the other is 80% occupied more mature properties and there we paid 130, 135 a foot much closer to replacing other good properties in good locations.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Of the 5% rent growth that you recorded this quarter, and when we look back in history, it looks like in the last cycle '05, '06 the peak of life cycle for you guys, you had several quarters where we had 5%, maybe one quarter at 6% and then sort of traile
componenttext: Of the 5% rent growth that you recorded this quarter, and when we look back in history, it looks like in the last cycle '05, '06 the peak of life cycle for you guys, you had several quarters where we had 5%, maybe one quarter at 6% and then sort of trailed off in '07 and beyond that, of course. But how do you think about the stellar rent growth in sort of the sustainability of that or even the prospects for new acceleration given that obviously, the macro environment is much softer than in the '05 and '06 recovery? Just how do you sort of reconcile that and does that make you more cautious on rent growth going forward compared to that time?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, '05, '06 was quite a while back. There were a couple of things that impacted our numbers in that period of time. Probably the most impactful, Michael, was hurricanes. I think there were 2 or 3 down in Florida, and that filled up most of our Florida
componenttext: Well, '05, '06 was quite a while back. There were a couple of things that impacted our numbers in that period of time. Probably the most impactful, Michael, was hurricanes. I think there were 2 or 3 down in Florida, and that filled up most of our Florida properties for a year or 2 with no promotional discounts. You could call it self-storage nirvana, and that was in our '05,  '06 numbers. We haven't had hurricanes down there for a while or they haven't impacted the storage facilities, so that's certainly a wild card in our operating results going forward. The other thing that impacted us in '07, '08 was the Shurgard Merger. If you recall about 8% to 10% lower occupancies than us. So that impacted our property occupancies pretty significantly during that period and part due to cannibalization. Going forward, I don't know if you asked me if we will be reporting 5% same-store revenue growth this quarter versus the exceptional performance we had last year, I would have said that wouldn't happen. So I've been surprised by the robustness of the business, as well as the fact that we're issuing 5 handled [ph] referred. I did not expect that last year. So my forecasting abilities aren't great. What I do know is we're in a great business, and it continues to perform well, and we've seen good demand across the country being able to drive -- hold move-in volume while reducing promotional discounts and media spend to me says a lot about the robustness of the business.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: The 1 billion of hypothetical acquisitions scenario that you outlined earlier and the challenges of getting there and the sort of minimal yield spread that you see, do you feel like that the trouble finding that level of acquisition volume is a function of the slow investment sales market or are you sort of approaching some kind of limit in terms of the properties that you're actually interested in acquiring from a preference standpoint.

componenttext: Yes, let me give you the same-store growth. Tampa was up 2.7% in the quarter, which is at the low end of our top 20. Orlando was up 4%. Miami was up 6.6%, one of our best performing markets in the quarter. So we've got Tampa, Orlando down at the lower growth end, and Miami just on fire there at 6.6%. Phoenix is not in our top 20. But its same-store revenue growth for the quarter was 1.2%. Vegas was pretty well flat but is moving up as well, and I expect that to be positive probably in the back half of the year and next year. I'm not sure if that addresses.

componenttext: I think we're grabbing at straws here, right, to figure out was growing on in this crazy world. Completely unrelated question, which is you don't have a massive acquisition slate at least it doesn't look like it. Development is almost nonexistent. componenttext: Well, I have a new COO to train here in the U.S. I have a new CEO in Europe, and I like to participate in acquisition opportunities. And then 2 weeks ago, I got Sean, our new COO. We spent a week in the car going through the Carolinas in Atlanta. So it's always good to get out in the field. So that's what I tend to do.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, final question from me. Why shouldn't we be seeing a notable pick up in development activity if conditions as robust as they are?
componenttext: Okay, final question from me. Why shouldn't we be seeing a notable pick up in development activity if conditions as robust as they are?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there is development activity. Why isn't it more robust? Probably due to financing. Certainly, the more well-capitalized regional operators have access to capital, and we've heard, we've seen a number of them talk about development some of t
componenttext: Well, I think there is development activity. Why isn't it more robust? Probably due to financing. Certainly, the more well-capitalized regional operators have access to capital, and we've heard, we've seen a number of them talk about development some of them are starting. But the majority of the product, which comes in the onesies [ph] and twosies [ph] everything we know of those guys are still having a big challenge in terms of getting financing to undertake development. And if you think about development as a whole, and we may have covered this last time over the last 10, 12 years there's probably been 15,000 facilities developed. I don't know the exact number, but the public companies contributed very, very small fraction of that. Most of it came from local people building 1 to 5 facilities, and those are the people that are well capital constrained at this time. Did that change going forward? It really depends on the banking industry. Does it make sense to build in some markets? Well, certainly in New York, if you can sell it $400 or $500 a foot. Can you build less than $400 or $500 a foot? Yes, New York market where make sense to build I think so.

componenttext: And then just thinking about you talked a little bit about the acquisitions that some of the public peers have done in terms of buying from their joint venture partners, they've also bought from their management platforms. And we talked a little bit about this on the last call. Have you given more thought of potentially making that a bigger part of the business A 1, just given the fact that you are operating margins and how you run your business about putting a managed asset in there is so valuable, and second, in order to create a larger ongoing pipeline of deals potentially for you to acquire?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. I would say if we were to really get going and I think touched on last quarter, I think we do 35, 40 properties, third-party management. We've been in that business since inception because when we first started Public Storage, when we starte
componenttext: Yes, Michael. I would say if we were to really get going and I think touched on last quarter, I think we do 35, 40 properties, third-party management. We've been in that business since inception because when we first started Public Storage, when we started out, we sold our properties, and we managed them. So we've been in the third-party business for 40 years. We would undertake third party overall as a business that made sense. As I've said before, filling up someone's property so I can turn around and buy it at a higher price I have trouble with the economics of that. But in terms of doing the third-party business and making it that business profitable, we're continuing to evaluate that.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then this is my last question. Just your sense of what's happened over the last year and just in terms of demand in the business and obviously being able to produce the rate increases that you have and continue to push occupancy even modestly over hig
componenttext: And then this is my last question. Just your sense of what's happened over the last year and just in terms of demand in the business and obviously being able to produce the rate increases that you have and continue to push occupancy even modestly over high levels, how much do think the public landlords have just been market share game versus incremental new demand of the storage business?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm sure we've taken some market share. But and I know that some other people talk about that as the big thing. But just step back and look at the fact that the public companies in aggregate have less than 10% share of the industry. Certainly some c
componenttext: Well, I'm sure we've taken some market share. But and I know that some other people talk about that as the big thing. But just step back and look at the fact that the public companies in aggregate have less than 10% share of the industry. Certainly some certain markets and for us, you take Seattle and Minneapolis where we're by far the dominant operators, the public companies really aren't there, and we have very good share, we've seen good demand in those markets. So I would say it's not really -- we're not taking away from the smaller operators that is aggregate demand for the product is good, is robust. So I don't think there's a material impact of this kind of market share thing between large and small operators because the large operators just have such a small fraction of the total industry.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Maria, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] After the speakers' remarks, there wil
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Maria, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. Thank you. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Clem Teng to begin. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, s
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC.
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, August 3, 2012, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and the audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. Our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.62 compared to $1.43 last year, a 13% increase. Five items contributed to this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 8.3%, adding $0.12 per share. Our non-same-store p
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. Our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.62 compared to $1.43 last year, a 13% increase. Five items contributed to this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 8.3%, adding $0.12 per share. Our non-same-store properties added $0.03. Last year's acquisition of affiliated partnership interests added $0.02, lower financing costs other added $0.04, ancillary operations, primarily our tenant reinsurance business, added $0.01. Partially offsetting this was $0.03 per share from lower interest income. 
We completed several capital transactions in the second quarter. We issued $288 million of preferred securities, with a rate of 5.625%, and called for redemption $416 million, with an average rate of 6.7%. Assuming no further reissuances, preferred dividends are expected to be about $8 million lower in the third quarter of 2012 as compared to last year. 
With that, I will now turn it over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The second quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record-high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q2, we reduced media spend by 44% or about $1.5 million, as well as promotional discounts. Net customer acquisition cost
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The second quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record-high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q2, we reduced media spend by 44% or about $1.5 million, as well as promotional discounts. 
Net customer acquisition cost declined as customer move-in volumes remained constant despite lower media and promotional discounts. At the end of July 2012, occupancy, asking rents and in-place rents were all higher than the same period last year. 
In Q2, Denver and Charlotte markets led the country with revenue growth of 8.7%, followed by Miami and Detroit at 6.6%. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew 4.4%; and San Francisco, our second largest market, grew -- revenues increased by 6.2%. 
Given the trends in our occupancies and rates, we expect our Q3 media spend will be comparable to last year. In Europe, same-store NOI improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. 
We recently completed the purchase of 5 facilities with about 377,000 square feet for $52 million. We're currently under contract to acquire 2 more facilities for about $30 million. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just in regards to Europe, your occupancy has slipped a little bit overall even from Q1, but you've still been able to see some decent growth in realized rents. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about your overall revenue management strategy th
componenttext: Just in regards to Europe, your occupancy has slipped a little bit overall even from Q1, but you've still been able to see some decent growth in realized rents. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about your overall revenue management strategy there, and what makes sense, sort of given the different environment you're operating in versus the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Christy, last year, we had some really aggressive promotional discounts in a couple of markets, which we did not do this year because the -- we kind of didn't get the benefit in terms of rate and promotional discounts versus move-in volume, so we've moder
componenttext: Christy, last year, we had some really aggressive promotional discounts in a couple of markets, which we did not do this year because the -- we kind of didn't get the benefit in terms of rate and promotional discounts versus move-in volume, so we've moderated those this year. So you've seen some degradation in occupancy and an uptick in the in-place rents and the rental revenue and lowered promotional discounts. And that varies by market, and the operating results, vary greatly by market, were on a revenue-growth basis. France was down 1.6% on same-store basis, whereas the U.K. was up 3.5% and Belgium was up almost 7%. So it varies by market. So what you're seeing is a blend, but the big picture is better pricing and reduced discounts this year with some impact on move-in volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the U.K. Can you talk about how the VAT tax issue could potentially impact the platform overall? I wasn't sure sort of what the breakout looks like in terms of residential versus commercial? And how does it impact sort of your perspec
componenttext: Just following up on the U.K. Can you talk about how the VAT tax issue could potentially impact the platform overall? I wasn't sure sort of what the breakout looks like in terms of residential versus commercial? And how does it impact sort of your perspective about investing additional capital there?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a lot of questions there. Basically, I don't think the -- I think the VAT tax is going to be negative. That's effectively a 20% price increase. And we've been told that, in fact, that's going in place on October 1. So my guess is it will be n
componenttext: Well, that's a lot of questions there. Basically, I don't think the -- I think the VAT tax is going to be negative. That's effectively a 20% price increase. And we've been told that, in fact, that's going in place on October 1. So my guess is it will be negative. How much, we don't know. I think we have 25%, 30% business customers. So obviously, they won't pay it, but the retail customer will be paying it.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Eric Wolfe with Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Eric Wolfe with Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's actually Michael Bilerman. Ron, I'm just curious, with occupancy getting back towards what is historically peak-ish levels and more of your revenue growth coming from rate, how much further do you think you can push rate increases on your customers?
componenttext: It's actually Michael Bilerman. Ron, I'm just curious, with occupancy getting back towards what is historically peak-ish levels and more of your revenue growth coming from rate, how much further do you think you can push rate increases on your customers? And sort of where are you sort of sending out renewal notices today?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is John. We are still pushing rental rate increases to existing tenants. We're sending out as many renewals this year as we did last year. The rate increases are higher this year than last year. Can we continue to do that into next year? We'
componenttext: Michael, this is John. We are still pushing rental rate increases to existing tenants. We're sending out as many renewals this year as we did last year. The rate increases are higher this year than last year. Can we continue to do that into next year? We're going to continue to try to do that. We see no reason why we couldn't do that. Part of our revenue growth was also driven by reductions in discounts, as Ron mentioned. So we picked up a good chunk of growth in the second quarter by reducing discounts to those new incoming tenants. So we're continuing to drive our revenues mostly with increases to existing tenants but also with reduced discounts to new incoming tenants.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And what would the discounts have been in terms of the spread relative to last year, in terms of impacting revenues?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
