componenttext: Of next year. So we expect deal should take that out with capital with preferred? And maybe I guess I jumped on late. So when you jump on late on public call, you miss the opening comments. Can you talk a little bit about Europe? And I apologize if you did just in terms of the operations but also the structure and the financing and how we should think about that going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, hereby I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI has improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe itself, our Eu
componenttext: Well, hereby I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI has improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe itself, our European operation would be what I would call a de-leveraging mode. Last year, we acquired the JV interest and refinanced it in the fourth quarter with a third-party loan from Wells Fargo. And we're taking our cash from operations and paying down that credit facility pursuant to its terms. Our hope is longer term sometime in '13, maybe '14 that our debt to EBITDA will get in the 4 to 4.5 range, and we hope to qualify for an investment grade rating at which time we will consider various opportunities to refinance out the balance of the Wells Fargo loan, as well as possibly the Public Storage intercompany debt.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt I guess. Can you make similar commentary today about how you feel now
componenttext: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt I guess. Can you make similar commentary today about how you feel now in the fourth quarter about where things stand and sort of your outlook for the rest of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- I know it's doing better than we anticipated, John, and I thought Europe would be pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year. And the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is backed about 300 basis po
componenttext: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- I know it's doing better than we anticipated, John, and I thought Europe would be pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year. And the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is backed about 300 basis points, in place rents are up about 3.5%. So we've been able to hold it in terms of the revenue line pretty well and pretty aggressive on cost management. So overall, it's a positive NOI year, which, quite frankly, surprising. Our toughest market continues to be Holland where we're at 73% occupied at the end of the quarter, which is down 6.5% from last year. Despite very aggressive rental rate reductions and promotional discounts, we've been very challenged to get traction there in Holland. Most of the other markets are kind of chugging along. France is a little soft. Denmark we've got some tough year-over-year comps. It was a big flood up in Denmark. London is doing great. Same-store NOI in London for the quarter was up 18% year-over-year, and occupancy and rates were up. So London's kind of the bright spot for us in Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then more just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how we'll trend for the rest of the qu
componenttext: And then more just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how we'll trend for the rest of the quarter.

componenttext: So we're coming into Q4 very stronger with higher year-over-year occupancies. Someone earlier asked about October occupancies they're at 92.3 versus 90.9. So they've gapped out about 1.4%, 1.5%. So we're heading into Q4 very strong. John touched on rates are about the same as last year. So we're feeling pretty good going into Q4 in the U.S.

componenttext: I don't think whether we issue 5% or 5.25% preferred changes what replacement cost has. Managing one side of the balance sheet is a little independent of the other.

componenttext: Okay, but so I guess let me ask you a different way. How aggressive would you be to perhaps gain additional exposure in some markets that are attractive to you today portfolio or significant opportunity sort of change the mindset somewhat? componenttext: Let me try to touch on be aggressive. We recently acquired 2 properties in Hawaii at 2 50 a foot? About 250 a foot probably at 10% or 15% premium to replacement cost. There are 2 probably 15 A properties in the Hawaii market. It was an off market deal. So we definitely paid up with that, we'll do that again yes. So A product and A markets in my mind we're very aggressive in terms of bidding were for that kind of product.

componenttext: I guess a bunch of my questions were answered in Europe, but just in general what are you seeing on the kind of the new development side I know you guys aren't really developing anything, but are you seeing anything changing on that? And is there a point at which you would actually kind of look to go back into development business?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Steve, as I've touched on previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large redevelo
componenttext: Steve, as I've touched on previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large redevelopment or a development redeveloping a existing building there in the Bronx. So yes, I think you're going to see us a little more aggressive on the development and redevelopment front in 2013.

componenttext: Ron, do you feel like there's sort of a practical cap on rent growth that you can achieve? Do you feel like you can get higher than that maybe next season or do you feel like just practically you can really get there above that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, just try so let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of leverage. One occupancy, which is volume. I touched on where occupancies are at the end of September where they are in October. So you're going to se
componenttext: Well, Michael, just try so let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of leverage. One occupancy, which is volume. I touched on where occupancies are at the end of September where they are in October. So you're going to see some growth in the rental revenue line from that gap in occupancy, which we hope to maintain or expand in Q4 and into Q1. The second thing is with respect to rental rate increases to existing customers and John can touch on that, but we've been running in a lot of our growth comes from that, and I think it's been 3.5% 4%, of our growth comes from those. And then the third factor that's been probably bigger impact in 2012 versus last 3 or 4 years is promotional discounts, which we've been able to modulate down especially during the second and third quarter due to our high occupancy. So going into 2013, if we're able to sustain the higher level of occupancies, we hope to be able to modulate further down the promotional discounts. We've got 3 drivers to the rental revenue line: discounts, volume and rental rate increases to existing customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012

componenttext: Okay, and then when we look at the operating expenses line, you're down a little over 0.5% for the year. Obviously, the media spend is down a lot. componenttext: I think there's some opportunities on the expense side going into 2013, not a lot but some. I would kind of go back to what I always tell people, and that is you should assume 2% to 3% expense growth on a long-term basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Discounts have clearly been a big part of the self-storage industry since almost its birth I would guess. It would seem to me that your ability to continue to I guess drive that level of discounts down, do you think that's more a function of what your pee
componenttext: Discounts have clearly been a big part of the self-storage industry since almost its birth I would guess. It would seem to me that your ability to continue to I guess drive that level of discounts down, do you think that's more a function of what your peers do that your subject in some respects to the advertising, the marketing of the broad market as opposed to what you want to do?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: In some respects yes, it's what our peers are doing Ross. But in a lot of respects, it's what our portfolio of tenants doing. They're staying longer there, more sticky now, which is enabling us to maintain occupancies without having to have the same neces
componenttext: In some respects yes, it's what our peers are doing Ross. But in a lot of respects, it's what our portfolio of tenants doing. They're staying longer there, more sticky now, which is enabling us to maintain occupancies without having to have the same necessarily the same level of move-in volume and getting away more and more promotion. So we're being conservative on the rate to get them in, but we're also being a little stingier on the discounts. And we've said this before the whole game and growing the revenues at least on the rate side is sending increases to the existing tenant base. And Ron had mentioned it although our tenant base, our aging tenant base roughly a little bit less than last year in absolute numbers, that is actually growing. So as we come back around to 2013, we hope that the tenant base will be continue to be more stable, and we will send out more increases in terms of absolute number of increases to tenants as we get into 2013. So it really a lot has to do with the stabilization of our tenant.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Understood. So that takes me to the next question, which is if street rates have been roughly flat year-over-year as you stand out the increases to existing customers, do you find I guess you'll find yourself in a position perhaps of having some level of
componenttext: Understood. So that takes me to the next question, which is if street rates have been roughly flat year-over-year as you stand out the increases to existing customers, do you find I guess you'll find yourself in a position perhaps of having some level of rent roll down on the portion of portfolio? Are you at that point yet?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always some rent roll down, but the increases that go on, we can send out increases of 9% to folks, and it will result in an uptick in move-out activity. But on a net-net basis with those who stay and paid the 9%, it's a big win for us. So a
componenttext: Well, there's always some rent roll down, but the increases that go on, we can send out increases of 9% to folks, and it will result in an uptick in move-out activity. But on a net-net basis with those who stay and paid the 9%, it's a big win for us. So and what we're seeing is that, that uptick and move-out activity is starting to diminish somewhat too. So again the tenant base is becoming more sticky. They're accepting the increases more and I think we're being a lot smarter and how we're going about setting out those increases. So yes.

componenttext: Well, we have 90 facilities in the New York, New Jersey market. componenttext: Well, about a little more than half of our move-in volume is coming from the Internet and be it the Internet from search engines, organic searches, mobile devices, what have you. And yes, it has started to change our way of how we spend advertising dollars. I mean, we do spend a lot of money on keyword search, as well as other Internet strategies. In fact, the bulk of our advertising spend is being done on the web for the most part.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-loo
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC.
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, November 9, 2012, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now, I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. I have a few comments on the impact of Hurricane Sandy. We have 90 facilities in the New York, New Jersey market of which 70 in our Same Store pool of properties. These 70 facilities generated approximately $27 million in revenues during
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. I have a few comments on the impact of Hurricane Sandy. We have 90 facilities in the New York, New Jersey market of which 70 in our Same Store pool of properties. These 70 facilities generated approximately $27 million in revenues during the third quarter. Within a few days, all of these facilities were open and operating. Damage to our facilities was minimal. We expect expenditures will be less than $1.5 million for repairs. 
With respect to third quarter earnings, our FFO -- our core FFO per share was $1.76 compared to $1.56 last year, a 13% increase. This growth was primarily driven by a 7.9% increase in our same-store net operating income of $0.13 per share and lower preferred stock dividends of $0.05 per share. 
As announced yesterday, we will be redeeming, on December 27, 3 series of our preferred securities totaling $363 million. As a result, we expect to record an EITF expense of approximately $12 million in the fourth quarter. 
With that, I will now turn it over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The third quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q3, customer acquisition costs declined, and customer move-ins increased by 6,200 or about 3%. Customer move-outs declined b
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The third quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q3, customer acquisition costs declined, and customer move-ins increased by 6,200 or about 3%. Customer move-outs declined by about 2,500. 
At the end of October, occupancy and in-place rents were higher than last year. Charlotte and Denver markets led the country with revenue growth of 8% followed by Houston and Miami with about 6%. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew by 4.4%. And San Francisco, our second largest market, increased by about 5.5%. In Europe, same-store NOI improved 2% despite a challenging operating environment. 
We recently acquired 8 facilities and have 2 others under contract. Total 2012 acquisition volume from third parties will be just over $200 million. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Todd, I'll let John address the pricing. If you recall, last year we start talking about how we were going to try to get our average occupancy for the year up. And due to the seasonality of our business, historically Q4 and Q1 have been 300 to 500 basis p
componenttext: Todd, I'll let John address the pricing. If you recall, last year we start talking about how we were going to try to get our average occupancy for the year up. And due to the seasonality of our business, historically Q4 and Q1 have been 300 to 500 basis points lower in occupancy versus Q2, Q3. So what we did at the beginning of this year and we're continuing here into the fourth quarter is really trying to drive that occupancy into Q4 so that we take some of the seasonality out of the business. You want to touch on pricing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Todd, to do that, we've been keeping our pricing pretty much consistent with prior year. So people that are moving in are moving in at rates that are pretty much flat on a year-over-year basis. So one of the things that we have been able to do is
componenttext: Yes. And Todd, to do that, we've been keeping our pricing pretty much consistent with prior year. So people that are moving in are moving in at rates that are pretty much flat on a year-over-year basis. So one of the things that we have been able to do is reduce the level of discounting that we've been giving up. So we've been able to gain occupancy, reduce discounts, but the move-in rate is about flat.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question, you mentioned the redemptions, the preferred redemptions, that were announced last night, another $300 million and change or so. I think that there's strong demand for your preferreds. Do you expect to begin to lever up
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, you mentioned the redemptions, the preferred redemptions, that were announced last night, another $300 million and change or so. I think that there's strong demand for your preferreds. Do you expect to begin to lever up a little bit and continue to issue new preferreds, or should we continue to see you delever at this point?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would expect that we will be in the market sometime in the next couple of months to try to issue additional preferred securities and take advantage of the current rate environment that's very favorable. So we're not -- we don't have it as a goal to dele
componenttext: I would expect that we will be in the market sometime in the next couple of months to try to issue additional preferred securities and take advantage of the current rate environment that's very favorable. So we're not -- we don't have it as a goal to delever the company per se. We're right now just trying to reduce the overall cost of capital to the company.

componenttext: Ron expects that I'm hoping that we can do it. So we will find out, but I don't know, Michael, right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then, Ron, just on the $200 million of acquisitions, can you guys just talk a little bit about sort of your appetite for investments, what you see out there because I think one challenge people have with your stock and one reason maybe it's not done a
componenttext: And then, Ron, just on the $200 million of acquisitions, can you guys just talk a little bit about sort of your appetite for investments, what you see out there because I think one challenge people have with your stock and one reason maybe it's not done as well lately is we're all accustomed to is the $200 million on your asset base is almost nothing. So maybe just talk about what you're seeing and why not be maybe a little more aggressive given your low cost of capital.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, as you've heard me say before, it's easy to buy real estate. All you have to do is show up with the biggest check. So that's not that hard to do. Buying real estate at or below replacement cost-quality assets, that's hard to do. So I think
componenttext: Well, Michael, as you've heard me say before, it's easy to buy real estate. All you have to do is show up with the biggest check. So that's not that hard to do. Buying real estate at or below replacement cost-quality assets, that's hard to do. So I think we pretty much have a no-lose strategy. 60% to 70% of the stuff we bought this year was distressed in one form or another and was acquired at substantial discount to replacement cost. The other stuff was either marketed or off-market deals. And so I'm very, very pleased with the acquisitions that we're doing. And as I said, I don't think we can really lose with that.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question for me would be just how this quarter's performance came in versus your own expectations.
componenttext: Okay. And then last question for me would be just how this quarter's performance came in versus your own expectations.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: A little better, a little better. We felt good coming out of Q2 with high occupancies. As we touched on in Q2, our promotional discounts were down. Media spend was down. And as we had in our second quarter call, the trend was good. So a little better, esp
componenttext: A little better, a little better. We felt good coming out of Q2 with high occupancies. As we touched on in Q2, our promotional discounts were down. Media spend was down. And as we had in our second quarter call, the trend was good. So a little better, especially on the expense side than we anticipated, but overall, about as planned.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the acquisition conversation, are you not seeing the kinds of opportunities that are attractive and meeting your investment criteria, or is there just a complete dearth of an opportunity set broadly? And sort of a corollary to that, ar
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the acquisition conversation, are you not seeing the kinds of opportunities that are attractive and meeting your investment criteria, or is there just a complete dearth of an opportunity set broadly? And sort of a corollary to that, are you considering selling any assets?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not considering selling any assets at this time. David Doll's here, so I'll let him give you some color on the acquisition market, but as I touched on with Michael, we look at properties. We look at replacement costs, and that's a key factor.
componenttext: Well, we're not considering selling any assets at this time. David Doll's here, so I'll let him give you some color on the acquisition market, but as I touched on with Michael, we look at properties. We look at replacement costs, and that's a key factor. And so sometimes we get outbid. But I'll let David give some more color on that.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ron. Paula, we're not seeing a real change in the product that's coming to market. There are plenty of assets in markets that we're not interested to come to market. And the quality properties in major metro markets, no real change in terms of
componenttext: Thank you, Ron. Paula, we're not seeing a real change in the product that's coming to market. There are plenty of assets in markets that we're not interested to come to market. And the quality properties in major metro markets, no real change in terms of product supply at this point in time.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the properties you acquired recently and the stuff you have under contract, how did those look like compared to your other properties in those respective MSAs just from an occupancy and a rent-per-square foot basis?
componenttext: Just looking at the properties you acquired recently and the stuff you have under contract, how did those look like compared to your other properties in those respective MSAs just from an occupancy and a rent-per-square foot basis?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, most of this stuff as I touched on, Todd, 70 -- 60% to 70% of the stuff that we've acquired this year was in one form of stress or not. And so usually those -- not usually, they're always under occupied, generally mispriced, lots of fill-up opportun
componenttext: Well, most of this stuff as I touched on, Todd, 70 -- 60% to 70% of the stuff that we've acquired this year was in one form of stress or not. And so usually those -- not usually, they're always under occupied, generally mispriced, lots of fill-up opportunities. People ask what cap rates. Well, some of them are operating at losses, some of them 1% or 2% yields. But we have enough market knowledge to know that, okay, we can attain a $2-a foot rent, $2.50 rent. And our surrounding properties are 92%, 93% occupied. So we're not too worried about achieving stabilized deals of 7%, 8% or 9% on those assets. But if you look at them on "what is the going in" yield, it's generally nominal and they're pretty under managed. Does that address your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, are the occupancies, say, 40% or they closer to, say, 70%?
componenttext: Yes, are the occupancies, say, 40% or they closer to, say, 70%?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Generally, the assets we bought this year are probably in the 50% to 70% range.
componenttext: Generally, the assets we bought this year are probably in the 50% to 70% range.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Wolfe with Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012

componenttext: Michael Bilerman with Eric. John, just in terms of the preferreds and you think about entering the market next year, with the redemptions announced last night, correct me if I'm wrong, the -- you have nothing left now from a redemption perspective until 2015, correct?

componenttext: That is correct, yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And so from -- I guess, you'll certainly feel the accretive effects from the amount that you did this year in lowering the average cost of that. But how should we think about, I guess, going forward any issuance than it just sits on cash until you use it
componenttext: And so from -- I guess, you'll certainly feel the accretive effects from the amount that you did this year in lowering the average cost of that. But how should we think about, I guess, going forward any issuance than it just sits on cash until you use it and with Ron's comments on the acquisition market, I would just take it that -- I don't know at what point would you issue them just to sit on cash?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, at that point, once we take care of, let's say, refinancing the $362 million that we called last night, we're not afraid to sit on cash. We've done that before. So we'll opportunistically issue preferred probably in 2013, put some cash on the balanc
componenttext: Well, at that point, once we take care of, let's say, refinancing the $362 million that we called last night, we're not afraid to sit on cash. We've done that before. So we'll opportunistically issue preferred probably in 2013, put some cash on the balance sheet and hopefully opportunities come our way and we can utilize that cash. But we want to make sure that we're taking advantage of the current rate environment and load up the balance sheet with some cash if we need to be.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, we also have about $250-or-so million of debt due in the first quarter.
componenttext: Michael, we also have about $250-or-so million of debt due in the first quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Of next year. So we should expect that you'll just take that out with capital -- with preferred? And how -- I guess, maybe just -- and I jumped on late. So when you jump on late to a Public Storage call, you miss the opening comments. Could you talk a lit
componenttext: Of next year. So we should expect that you'll just take that out with capital -- with preferred? And how -- I guess, maybe just -- and I jumped on late. So when you jump on late to a Public Storage call, you miss the opening comments. Could you talk a little bit about Europe, and I apologize if you did, just in terms of the operations but also the structure and financing and how we should think about that going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Europe, I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI was improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe, itself, our
componenttext: Well, Europe, I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI was improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe, itself, our European operation would be what I would call a deleveraging mode. Last year, we acquired the JV interest and refinanced it in the fourth quarter with a third-party loan from Wells Fargo. And we're taking our cash from operations and paying down that credit facility pursuant to its terms. Our hope is, longer term, sometime in '13, maybe '14, that our debt-to-EBITDA will get in the 4 to 4.5 range. And we hope to qualify for an investment grade rating at which time we'll consider various opportunities to refinance out the balance of the Wells Fargo loan as well as possibly the Public Storage intercompany debt.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt. I guess, can you make some more commentary today about how you feel
componenttext: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt. I guess, can you make some more commentary today about how you feel now in the fourth quarter about where things stand and sort of your outlook for the rest of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- well, I know it's doing better than we anticipated. John and I thought Europe would be a pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year, and the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is back about 300 bas
componenttext: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- well, I know it's doing better than we anticipated. John and I thought Europe would be a pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year, and the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is back about 300 basis points, in-place rents are up about 3.5%. So we've been able to hold it in terms of the revenue line pretty well and then pretty aggressive on cost management. So overall, it's a positive NOI year, which, quite frankly, is surprising. Our toughest market continues to be Holland where we're at 73% occupied at the end of the quarter, which is down 6.5% from last year. Despite very aggressive rental rate reductions and promotional discounts, we've been very challenged to get traction there in Holland. Most of the other markets are kind of chugging along. France is a little soft. Denmark, we've got some tough year-over-year comps. There was a big flood up in Denmark. London's doing great. Same-store NOI in London for the quarter was up 18% year-over-year and occupancy and rates were up. So London's kind of the bright spot for us in Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then more so about the just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business, whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year that -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how it will trend f
componenttext: And then more so about the just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business, whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year that -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how it will trend for the rest of the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: So we're coming into Q4 very strong with higher year-over-year occupancies. Someone else earlier asked about the October occupancies. They're at 92.3% versus 90.9%, so they've gapped out about 1.4%, 1.5%. So we're heading into Q4 very strong. John touched
componenttext: So we're coming into Q4 very strong with higher year-over-year occupancies. Someone else earlier asked about the October occupancies. They're at 92.3% versus 90.9%, so they've gapped out about 1.4%, 1.5%. So we're heading into Q4 very strong. John touched on rates are about the same as last year. So we're feeling pretty good going into Q4 in U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, I know you look at replacement costs, but does issuing preferreds at that 5 1/4% or even lower change the threshold that you'll pay for acquisitions?
componenttext: Ron, I know you look at replacement costs, but does issuing preferreds at that 5 1/4% or even lower change the threshold that you'll pay for acquisitions?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think whether we issue 5% or 5 1/4% preferred changes what replacement cost has. Managing one side of the balance sheet is a little independent of the other.
componenttext: I don't think whether we issue 5% or 5 1/4% preferred changes what replacement cost has. Managing one side of the balance sheet is a little independent of the other.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, but -- so I guess let me ask you a different way. How aggressive would you be to perhaps gain additional exposure in some markets that are attractive to you today? Does a portfolio or significant opportunity sort of change the mindset somewhat? And
componenttext: Okay, but -- so I guess let me ask you a different way. How aggressive would you be to perhaps gain additional exposure in some markets that are attractive to you today? Does a portfolio or significant opportunity sort of change the mindset somewhat? And would you pay a premium on a price-per-square foot basis with having such a low cost of capital today?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me try to touch on being aggressive. We recently acquired 2 properties in Hawaii at $250 a foot? About $250 a foot, probably a 10% or 15% premium to replacement costs. There are 2 probably of 15 A properties in the Hawaii market. It was an off-market
componenttext: Let me try to touch on being aggressive. We recently acquired 2 properties in Hawaii at $250 a foot? About $250 a foot, probably a 10% or 15% premium to replacement costs. There are 2 probably of 15 A properties in the Hawaii market. It was an off-market deal. So we definitely paid up for that. We'll we do that again? Yes. So A product in A markets, in my mind, we're very aggressive in terms of bidding were for that kind of product.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Laughlin with ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Laughlin with ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron and John, it's Steve. I guess, a bunch of my questions were answered on Europe. But just in general, what are you seeing on kind of the new development side? I know you guys aren't really developing anything. But are you seeing anything changing on th
componenttext: Ron and John, it's Steve. I guess, a bunch of my questions were answered on Europe. But just in general, what are you seeing on kind of the new development side? I know you guys aren't really developing anything. But are you seeing anything changing on that? And is there a point at which you would actually kind of look to go back into the development business?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Steve, as I've touched on, on previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large rede
componenttext: Steve, as I've touched on, on previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large redevelopment or a development -- we're redeveloping a existing building there in the Bronx. So yes, I think you're going to see us a little more aggressive on the development and redevelopment front in 2013.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, do you feel like there's sort of a practical cap on rent growth that you can achieve? I think in the last cycle, you guys kind of peaked out at maybe at 5% -- 5% or 6% type of realized rent growth and that's almost where you're at here. Do you feel l
componenttext: Ron, do you feel like there's sort of a practical cap on rent growth that you can achieve? I think in the last cycle, you guys kind of peaked out at maybe at 5% -- 5% or 6% type of realized rent growth and that's almost where you're at here. Do you feel like you can get higher than that maybe next rental season or do you feel like just practically you can't really get there above that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, just try to -- let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of leverage. One, occupancy, which is volume. I've touched on where occupancies are at the end of September, where they are in October. So you're goi
componenttext: Well, Michael, just try to -- let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of leverage. One, occupancy, which is volume. I've touched on where occupancies are at the end of September, where they are in October. So you're going to see some growth in the rental revenue line from that gap in occupancy, which we hope to maintain or expand in Q4 and into Q1. The second thing is with respect to rental rate increases to existing customers and John can touch on that, but we've been running -- a lot of our growth comes from that and I think it's been 3.5%, 4% of our growth comes from those. And then the third factor that's been probably bigger impact in 2012 versus last 3 or 4 years is promotional discounts, which we've been able to modulate down, especially during the second and third quarter due to our high occupancy. So going into 2013, if we're able to sustain the higher level of occupancies, we hope to be able to modulate further down the promotional discounts. We've got 3 drivers to the rental revenue line: discounts, volume and rental rate increases to existing customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we look at the operating expense line, you're down a little over 0.5% for the year. Obviously, the media spend is down a lot. Do you feel like that number starts to stabilize next year? Do you feel like there's continued savings there
componenttext: Okay. And then when we look at the operating expense line, you're down a little over 0.5% for the year. Obviously, the media spend is down a lot. Do you feel like that number starts to stabilize next year? Do you feel like there's continued savings there as you get even better at the Internet marketing side of the shop?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think there's some opportunities on the expense side going into 2013, not a lot, but some. I would kind of go back to what I always tell people and that is you should assume a 2% to 3% expense growth on a long-term basis.
componenttext: I think there's some opportunities on the expense side going into 2013, not a lot, but some. I would kind of go back to what I always tell people and that is you should assume a 2% to 3% expense growth on a long-term basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, but does that start next year? It sounds like maybe not.
componenttext: Yes, but does that start next year? It sounds like maybe not.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'm not going to give you guidance. Thank you.
componenttext: Michael, I'm not going to give you guidance. Thank you.

componenttext: Last question would be just in terms of the $200 million of acquisitions for the year. Do you feel like that's sort of a baseline level that you could probably exceed next year or do you feel like that is sort of a fair betting line for next year as well?

componenttextpreview: I'd like to see us do $1 billion of acquisitions next year.
componenttext: I'd like to see us do $1 billion of acquisitions next year.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two quick things. One, Ron, I was wondering you mentioned Hawaii acquisition. You paid up for that. Can you throw out what the cap rate was or range on that? And then also on G&A, I think it was a quarter or 2 ago you were talking about maybe about a $50
componenttext: Two quick things. One, Ron, I was wondering you mentioned Hawaii acquisition. You paid up for that. Can you throw out what the cap rate was or range on that? And then also on G&A, I think it was a quarter or 2 ago you were talking about maybe about a $50 million, $51 million run rate. Q3, it popped a little bit compared to prior quarters and I think your year-to-date's about $44 million, $45 million or so. Just wondering what you're thinking on a go-forward basis there.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll let John address the G&A. The cap rate on Hawaii properties I think the going in was about 2%, 2.5% and they're about 45%, 50% occupied.
componenttext: I'll let John address the G&A. The cap rate on Hawaii properties I think the going in was about 2%, 2.5% and they're about 45%, 50% occupied.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And on G&A, Mike, most of the pop was due to stock-based compensation. We had a little higher expenditures and legal fees. Expect a run rate for 2012 to be somewhere in the $57 million range. And then 2013, I would assume, as Ron said, an inflater of that
componenttext: And on G&A, Mike, most of the pop was due to stock-based compensation. We had a little higher expenditures and legal fees. Expect a run rate for 2012 to be somewhere in the $57 million range. And then 2013, I would assume, as Ron said, an inflater of that.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, can you talk about the discounts? Maybe I can tackle it a little different way. What percentage of customers who moved in, in the third quarter received discounts versus the same quarter year ago?
componenttext: Ron, can you talk about the discounts? Maybe I can tackle it a little different way. What percentage of customers who moved in, in the third quarter received discounts versus the same quarter year ago?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Do you have that?
componenttext: Do you have that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Roughly about 82% probably were getting discounts, Ross, versus maybe about 92% last year.
componenttext: Roughly about 82% probably were getting discounts, Ross, versus maybe about 92% last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Discounts have clearly been a big part of the self-storage industry since almost its birth, I would guess. It would seem to me that your ability to continue to, I guess, drive that level of discounts down, do you think that's more a function of what your
componenttext: Discounts have clearly been a big part of the self-storage industry since almost its birth, I would guess. It would seem to me that your ability to continue to, I guess, drive that level of discounts down, do you think that's more a function of what your peers do that you're subject in some respects to the advertising and the marketing of the broad market as opposed to what you want to do?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: In some respects yes, it's what our peers are doing Ross. But in a lot of respects, it's what our portfolio of tenants are doing. They're staying longer. They're more sticky now, which is enabling us to maintain occupancies without having to have the same
componenttext: In some respects yes, it's what our peers are doing Ross. But in a lot of respects, it's what our portfolio of tenants are doing. They're staying longer. They're more sticky now, which is enabling us to maintain occupancies without having to have the same -- necessarily the same level of move-in volume and giving away more and more promotion. So we're being conservative on the rate to get them in, but we're also being a little stingier on the discounts. And we've said this before the whole game and growing the revenues, at least on the rate side, is sending increases to the existing tenant base. And Ron had mentioned that although our tenant base -- our aging tenant base is roughly a little bit less than last year, in absolute numbers that is actually growing. So as we come back around to 2013, we hope that the tenant base will be -- continue to be more stable and we will send out more increases in terms of absolute number of increases to tenants as we get into 2013. So it's really -- a lot has to do with the stabilization of our tenants.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Understood. So that takes me to the next question, which is if street rates have been roughly flat year-over-year, as you send out the increases to existing customers, do you find -- I guess you'll find yourself in a position perhaps of having some level
componenttext: Understood. So that takes me to the next question, which is if street rates have been roughly flat year-over-year, as you send out the increases to existing customers, do you find -- I guess you'll find yourself in a position perhaps of having some level of rent roll-down on the portion of portfolio? Are you at that point yet?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always some rent roll-down, but on the increases that go on, we can send out increases of 9% to folks and it will result in an uptick in move-out activity. But on a net-net basis for those who stay and paid the 9%, it's a big win for us, so
componenttext: Well, there's always some rent roll-down, but on the increases that go on, we can send out increases of 9% to folks and it will result in an uptick in move-out activity. But on a net-net basis for those who stay and paid the 9%, it's a big win for us, so -- and what we are seeing is that, that uptick in move-out activity is starting to diminish somewhat, too. So again, the tenant base is becoming more sticky. They're accepting the increases more. And I think we're being a lot smarter in how we're going about sending out those increases, so yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And last quick one from me. In your best markets, Ron, that you alluded to, are you seeing anything different from an economic perspective versus your worst markets? So is it a function of better job growth, migration patterns? Can you isolate anything th
componenttext: And last quick one from me. In your best markets, Ron, that you alluded to, are you seeing anything different from an economic perspective versus your worst markets? So is it a function of better job growth, migration patterns? Can you isolate anything that's driving the good versus the bad markets?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ross, John and I were talking about this the other day. And pretty much across the portfolio, business is good whether it's Kansas City, Austin, San Francisco, Houston, Miami. Across the portfolio, it's good. Probably our softer market is somewhere in the
componenttext: Ross, John and I were talking about this the other day. And pretty much across the portfolio, business is good whether it's Kansas City, Austin, San Francisco, Houston, Miami. Across the portfolio, it's good. Probably our softer market is somewhere in the Northeast, Philly, D.C. but it's still good.

componenttext: Well, about a little more than 1/2 of our move-in volume is coming from the Internet, be it the Internet from search engines, organic searches, mobile devices, what have you. In fact, the bulk of our advertising spend is being done on the web for the most part.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-loo
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC.
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, November 9, 2012, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now, I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. I have a few comments on the impact of Hurricane Sandy. We have 90 facilities in the New York, New Jersey market of which 70 in our Same Store pool of properties. These 70 facilities generated approximately $27 million in revenues during
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. I have a few comments on the impact of Hurricane Sandy. We have 90 facilities in the New York, New Jersey market of which 70 in our Same Store pool of properties. These 70 facilities generated approximately $27 million in revenues during the third quarter. Within a few days, all of these facilities were open and operating. Damage to our facilities was minimal. We expect expenditures will be less than $1.5 million for repairs. 
With respect to third quarter earnings, our FFO -- our core FFO per share was $1.76 compared to $1.56 last year, a 13% increase. This growth was primarily driven by a 7.9% increase in our same-store net operating income for $0.13 per share and lower preferred stock dividends of $0.05 per share. 
As announced yesterday, we will be redeeming, on December 27, 3 series of our preferred securities totaling $363 million. As a result, we expect to record an EITF expense of approximately $12 million in the fourth quarter. 
With that, I will now turn it over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The third quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q3, customer acquisition costs declined, and customer move-ins increased by 6,200 or about 3%. Customer move-outs declined b
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The third quarter benefited from solid demand, resulting in record high occupancies and higher realized rents. In Q3, customer acquisition costs declined, and customer move-ins increased by 6,200 or about 3%. Customer move-outs declined by about 2,500. 
At the end of October, occupancy and in-place rents were higher than last year. The Charlotte and Denver markets led the country with revenue growth of 8% followed by Houston and Miami with about 6%. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew by 4.4%. And San Francisco, our second largest market, increased by about 5.5%. In Europe, same-store NOI improved 2% despite a challenging operating environment. 
We recently acquired 8 facilities and have 2 others under contract. Total 2012 acquisition volume for third parties will be just over $200 million. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: Todd, I'll let John address the pricing. If you recall, last year we started talking about how we were going to try to get our average occupancy for the year up. And due to the seasonality of our business, historically Q4 and Q1 have been 300 to 500 basis
componenttext: Todd, I'll let John address the pricing. If you recall, last year we started talking about how we were going to try to get our average occupancy for the year up. And due to the seasonality of our business, historically Q4 and Q1 have been 300 to 500 basis points lower in occupancy versus Q2, Q3. So what we did at the beginning of this year and we're continuing here into the fourth quarter is really trying to drive that occupancy into Q4 so that we take some of the seasonality out of the business. You want to touch on pricing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Todd, to do that, we've been keeping our pricing pretty much consistent with prior year. So people that are moving in are moving in at rates that are pretty much flat on a year-over-year basis. So one of the things that we have been able to do is
componenttext: Yes. And Todd, to do that, we've been keeping our pricing pretty much consistent with prior year. So people that are moving in are moving in at rates that are pretty much flat on a year-over-year basis. So one of the things that we have been able to do is reduce the level of discounting that we've been giving up. So we've been able to gain occupancy, reduce discounts, but the move-in rate is about flat.

componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, you mentioned the redemptions, the preferred redemptions, that were announced last night, another $300 million and change or so. headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would expect that we will be in the market sometime in the next couple of months to try to issue additional preferred securities and take advantage of the current rate environment that's very favorable. So we're not -- we don't have it as a goal to dele
componenttext: I would expect that we will be in the market sometime in the next couple of months to try to issue additional preferred securities and take advantage of the current rate environment that's very favorable. So we're not -- we don't have it as a goal to delever the company per se. We're right now just trying to reduce the overall cost of capital to the company.

componenttext: And then, Ron, just on the $200 million of acquisitions, can you guys just talk a little bit about sort of your appetite for investments, what you see out there because I think one challenge people have with your stock and one reason maybe it's not done as well lately is we're all accustomed to is the $200 million on your asset base is almost nothing. So maybe just talk about what you're seeing and why not be maybe a little more aggressive given your low cost of capital.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, as you've heard me say before, it's easy to buy real estate. All you have to do is show up with the biggest check. So that's not that hard to do. Buying real estate at or below replacement cost-quality assets, that's hard to do. So I think
componenttext: Well, Michael, as you've heard me say before, it's easy to buy real estate. All you have to do is show up with the biggest check. So that's not that hard to do. Buying real estate at or below replacement cost-quality assets, that's hard to do. So I think we pretty much have a no-lose strategy. 60% to 70% of the stuff we bought this year was distressed in one form or another and was acquired at substantial discount to replacement cost. The other stuff was either marketed or off-market deals. And so I'm very, very pleased with the acquisitions that we're doing. And as I said, I don't think we can really lose with that.

componenttext: A little better, a little better. We felt good coming out of Q2 with high occupancies. As we touched on in Q2, our promotional discounts were down. Media spend was down. And as we had in our second quarter call, the trend was good. So a little better, especially on the expense side than we anticipated, but overall, about as planned.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, most of this stuff as I touched on, Todd, 70 -- 60% to 70% of the stuff that we've acquired this year was in one form of stress or not. And so usually those -- not usually, they're always under occupied, generally mispriced, lots of fill-up opportun
componenttext: Well, most of this stuff as I touched on, Todd, 70 -- 60% to 70% of the stuff that we've acquired this year was in one form of stress or not. And so usually those -- not usually, they're always under occupied, generally mispriced, lots of fill-up opportunities. People ask what cap rates. Well, some of them are operating at losses, some of them are at 1% or 2% yields. But we have enough market knowledge to know that, okay, we can attain a $2-a foot rent, $2.50 rent. And our surrounding properties are 92%, 93% occupied. So we're not too worried about achieving a stabilized yield of 7%, 8% or 9% on those assets. But if you look at them on "what is the going in" yield, it's generally nominal and they're pretty under managed. Does that address your question?

componenttext: Well, at that point, once we take care of, let's say, refinancing the $362 million that we called last night, we're not afraid to sit on cash. We've done that before. So we'll opportunistically issue preferred probably in 2013, put some cash on the balance sheet and hopefully opportunities come our way and we can utilize that cash. But we want to make sure that we're taking advantage of the current rate environment and load up the balance sheet with some cash if we need to be.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Europe, I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI was improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe, itself, our
componenttext: Well, Europe, I made the comment, Michael, that same-store NOI was improved by 2% despite a challenging operating environment. That NOI growth was principally achieved by expense reduction, principally in the R&M and advertising area. Europe, itself, our European operation would be in what I would call a deleveraging mode. Last year, we acquired the JV interest and refinanced it in the fourth quarter with a third-party loan from Wells Fargo. And we're taking our cash from operations and paying down that credit facility pursuant to its terms. Our hope is, longer term, sometime in '13, maybe '14, that our debt-to-EBITDA will get in the 4 to 4.5 range. And we hope to qualify for an investment grade rating at which time we'll consider various opportunities to refinance out the balance of the Wells Fargo loan as well as possibly the Public Storage intercompany debt.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt. I guess, can you make some more commentary today about how you feel
componenttext: And just last question. You just commented in terms of your feelings about how you performed in the third quarter and you made comments about heading into the third quarter how you felt. I guess, can you make some more commentary today about how you feel now in the fourth quarter about where things stand and sort of your outlook for the rest of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- well, I know it's doing better than we anticipated. John and I thought Europe would be a pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year, and the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is back about 300 bas
componenttext: Yes. Overall, I think Europe is -- well, I know it's doing better than we anticipated. John and I thought Europe would be a pretty negative same-store NOI growth this year, and the team over there has done a good job. While occupancy is back about 300 basis points, in-place rents are up about 3.5%. So we've been able to hold it in terms of the revenue line pretty well and then been pretty aggressive on cost management. So overall, it's a positive NOI year, which, quite frankly, is surprising. Our toughest market continues to be Holland where we're at 73% occupied at the end of the quarter, which is down 6.5% from last year. Despite very aggressive rental rate reductions and promotional discounts, we've been very challenged to get traction there in Holland. Most of the other markets are kind of chugging along. France is a little soft. Denmark, we've got some tough year-over-year comps. There was a big flood up in Denmark. London's doing great. Same-store NOI in London for the quarter was up 18% year-over-year and occupancy and rates are up. So London's kind of the bright spot for us in Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I meant more so about the just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business, whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year that -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how it will trend fo
componenttext: I meant more so about the just sort of your optimism or pessimism for the fourth quarter in the U.S. business, whether there's anything in the first effectively 6 weeks of the year that -- 6 weeks of the quarter that you sort of think how it will trend for the rest of the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: So we're coming into Q4 very strong with higher year-over-year occupancies. Someone else earlier asked about the October occupancies. They're at 92.3% versus 90.9%, so they've gapped out about 1.4%, 1.5%. So we're heading into Q4 very strong. John touched
componenttext: So we're coming into Q4 very strong with higher year-over-year occupancies. Someone else earlier asked about the October occupancies. They're at 92.3% versus 90.9%, so they've gapped out about 1.4%, 1.5%. So we're heading into Q4 very strong. John touched on rates are about the same as last year. So we're feeling pretty good going into Q4 in U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, I know you look at replacement costs, but does issuing preferreds at that 5 1/4% or even lower change the threshold that you'll pay for acquisitions?
componenttext: Ron, I know you look at replacement costs, but does issuing preferreds at that 5 1/4% or even lower change the threshold that you'll pay for acquisitions?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think whether we issue 5% or 5 1/4% preferred changes what replacement cost has. Managing one side of the balance sheet is a little independent of the other.
componenttext: I don't think whether we issue 5% or 5 1/4% preferred changes what replacement cost has. Managing one side of the balance sheet is a little independent of the other.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, but -- so I guess let me ask you a different way. How aggressive would you be to perhaps gain additional exposure in some markets that are attractive to you today? Does a portfolio or significant opportunity sort of change the mindset somewhat? And
componenttext: Okay, but -- so I guess let me ask you a different way. How aggressive would you be to perhaps gain additional exposure in some markets that are attractive to you today? Does a portfolio or significant opportunity sort of change the mindset somewhat? And would you pay a premium on a price-per-square foot basis with having such a low cost of capital today?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me try to touch on being aggressive. We recently acquired 2 properties in Hawaii at $250 a foot? About $250 a foot, probably a 10% or 15% premium to replacement costs. There are 2 probably of 15 A properties in the Hawaii market. It was an off-market
componenttext: Let me try to touch on being aggressive. We recently acquired 2 properties in Hawaii at $250 a foot? About $250 a foot, probably a 10% or 15% premium to replacement costs. There are 2 probably of 15 A properties in the Hawaii market. It was an off-market deal. So we definitely paid up for that. We'll we do that again? Yes. So A product in A markets, in my mind, we're very aggressive in terms of bidding or -- for that kind of product.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Laughlin with ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Laughlin with ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron and John, it's Steve. I guess, a bunch of my questions were answered on Europe. But just in general, what are you seeing on kind of the new development side? I know you guys aren't really developing anything. But are you seeing anything changing on th
componenttext: Ron and John, it's Steve. I guess, a bunch of my questions were answered on Europe. But just in general, what are you seeing on kind of the new development side? I know you guys aren't really developing anything. But are you seeing anything changing on that? And is there a point at which you would actually kind of look to go back into the development business?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Steve, as I've touched on, in previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large rede
componenttext: Steve, as I've touched on, in previous quarters, I think development is inevitable. We're starting to see it. We've been seeing it this year around the country in various markets. We took down a property in New York that you could consider it a large redevelopment or a development -- we're redeveloping a existing building there in the Bronx. So yes, I think you're going to see us a little more aggressive on the development and redevelopment front in 2013.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ron, do you feel like there's sort of a practical cap on rent growth that you can achieve? I think in the last cycle, you guys kind of peaked out at maybe at 5% -- 5% or 6% type of realized rent growth and that's almost where you're at here. Do you feel l
componenttext: Ron, do you feel like there's sort of a practical cap on rent growth that you can achieve? I think in the last cycle, you guys kind of peaked out at maybe at 5% -- 5% or 6% type of realized rent growth and that's almost where you're at here. Do you feel like you can get higher than that maybe next rental season or do you feel like just practically you can't really get there -- above that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, just try to -- let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of levers. One, occupancy, which is volume. I've touched on where our occupancies are at the end of September, where they are in October. So you're g
componenttext: Well, Michael, just try to -- let's think about rent growth here for a couple of things. There's a couple of levers. One, occupancy, which is volume. I've touched on where our occupancies are at the end of September, where they are in October. So you're going to see some growth in the rental revenue line from that gap in occupancy, which we hope to maintain or expand in Q4 and into Q1. The second thing is with respect to rental rate increases to existing customers and John can touch on that, but we've been running -- a lot of our growth comes from that and I think it's been 3.5%, 4% of our growth comes from those. And then the third factor that's been a -- probably a bigger impact in 2012 versus last 3 or 4 years is promotional discounts, which we've been able to modulate down, especially during the second and third quarter due to our high occupancy. So going into 2013, if we're able to sustain the higher level of occupancies, we hope to be able to modulate further down the promotional discounts. We've got 3 drivers to the rental revenue line: discounts, volume and rental rate increases to existing customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we look at the operating expense line, you're down a little over 0.5% for the year. Obviously, the media spend is down a lot. Do you feel like that number starts to stabilize next year? Do you feel like there's continued savings there
componenttext: Okay. And then when we look at the operating expense line, you're down a little over 0.5% for the year. Obviously, the media spend is down a lot. Do you feel like that number starts to stabilize next year? Do you feel like there's continued savings there as you get even better at the Internet marketing side of the shop?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think there's some opportunities on the expense side going into 2013, not a lot, but some. I would kind of go back to what I always tell people and that is you should assume a 2% to 3% expense growth on a long-term basis.
componenttext: I think there's some opportunities on the expense side going into 2013, not a lot, but some. I would kind of go back to what I always tell people and that is you should assume a 2% to 3% expense growth on a long-term basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, but does that start next year? It sounds like maybe not.
componenttext: Yes, but does that start next year? It sounds like maybe not.

componenttext: Michael, I'm not going to give you guidance. Thank you.

componenttext: Last question would be just in terms of the $200 million of acquisitions for the year. Do you feel like that's sort of a baseline level that you could probably exceed next year or do you feel like that is sort of a fair betting line for next year as well?

componenttextpreview: I'd like to see us do $1 billion of acquisitions next year.
componenttext: I'd like to see us do $1 billion of acquisitions next year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two quick things. One, Ron, I was wondering you mentioned Hawaii acquisition. You paid up for that. Can you throw out what the cap rate was or range on that? And then also on G&A, I think it was a quarter or 2 ago you were talking about maybe about a $50
componenttext: Two quick things. One, Ron, I was wondering you mentioned Hawaii acquisition. You paid up for that. Can you throw out what the cap rate was or range on that? And then also on G&A, I think it was a quarter or 2 ago you were talking about maybe about a $50 million, $51 million run rate. Q3, it popped a little bit compared to prior quarters and I think your year-to-date's about $44 million, $45 million or so. Just wondering what you're thinking on a go-forward basis there.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll let John address G&A. The cap rate on Hawaii properties I think the going in was about 2%, 2.5% and they're about 45%, 50% occupied.
componenttext: I'll let John address G&A. The cap rate on Hawaii properties I think the going in was about 2%, 2.5% and they're about 45%, 50% occupied.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And on G&A, Mike, most of the pop was due to stock-based compensation. We had a little higher in expenditures and legal fees. Expect a run rate for 2012 to be somewhere in the $57 million range. And then 2013, I would assume, as Ron said, an inflater off
componenttext: And on G&A, Mike, most of the pop was due to stock-based compensation. We had a little higher in expenditures and legal fees. Expect a run rate for 2012 to be somewhere in the $57 million range. And then 2013, I would assume, as Ron said, an inflater off of that.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2012
